etymologies: Middle English (as a verb): from Old French estreindre, from Latin stringere ‘draw tight’. Current senses of the noun arose in the mid 16th century

definitions: force (a part of one's body or oneself) to make a strenuous or unusually great effort

examples.text: I stopped and listened, straining my ears for any sound

shortDefinitions: force to make unusually great effort

definitions: make a strenuous and continuous effort

examples.text: his voice was so quiet that I had to strain to hear it

shortDefinitions: make unusually great effort

definitions: injure (a limb, muscle, or organ) by overexerting it or twisting it awkwardly

examples.text: on cold days you are more likely to strain a muscle
glare from the screen can strain your eyes

shortDefinitions: injure limb, muscle, or organ by overexerting it

definitions: make severe or excessive demands on

examples.text: he strained her tolerance to the limit

shortDefinitions: make severe or excessive demands on

definitions: pull or push forcibly at something

examples.text: the bear strained at the chain around its neck
his stomach was swollen, straining against the thin shirt

shortDefinitions: pull or push forcibly at something

definitions: stretch (something) tightly

examples.text: the barbed wire fence was strained to posts six feet high

shortDefinitions: stretch something tightly

definitions: embrace (someone) tightly

examples.text: she strained the infant to her bosom again

shortDefinitions: embrace someone tightly

definitions: pour (a mainly liquid substance) through a porous or perforated device or material in order to separate out any solid matter

examples.text: strain the custard into a bowl

shortDefinitions: pour mainly liquid substance through porous or perforated device or material

definitions: cause liquid to drain off (food that has been boiled, soaked, or canned) by pouring through a perforated device

examples.text: she turned to the sink to strain the noodles

shortDefinitions: cause liquid to drain off by using porous or perforated device

definitions: drain off (liquid) by straining

examples.text: strain off the surplus fat

shortDefinitions: drain off liquid by using porous or perforated device

definitions: a force tending to pull or stretch something to an extreme or damaging degree

examples.text: the usual type of chair puts an enormous strain on the spine
aluminum may bend under strain

shortDefinitions: force tending to pull or stretch something to extreme or damaging degree

definitions: an injury to a part of the body caused by overexertion or twisting a muscle awkwardly

examples.text: he has a slight groin strain

shortDefinitions: injury to part of body caused by overexertion

definitions: the magnitude of a deformation, equal to the change in the dimension of a deformed object divided by its original dimension.
shortDefinitions: magnitude of deformation, equal to change in dimension of deformed object

definitions: a severe or excessive demand on the strength, resources, or abilities of someone or something

examples.text: the accusations put a strain on relations between the two countries
she's obviously under considerable strain

shortDefinitions: severe or excessive demand on strength

definitions: a state of tension or exhaustion resulting from severe demands on one's strength or resources

examples.text: the telltale signs of nervous strain

shortDefinitions: state of tension or exhaustion resulting from severe demands on one's strength or resources

definitions: the sound of a piece of music as it is played or performed

examples.text: through the open windows came the strains of a hurdy-gurdy playing in the street

shortDefinitions: sound of piece of music

etymologies: Old English strīon ‘acquisition, gain’, of Germanic origin; related to Latin struere ‘to build up’

definitions: a breed, stock, or variety of an animal or plant developed by breeding.
shortDefinitions: particular breed, stock, or variety of animal or plant

definitions: a natural or cultured variety of a microorganism with a distinct form, biochemistry, or virulence.
shortDefinitions: natural or cultured variety of microorganism

definitions: a variety of a particular abstract thing

examples.text: a strain of music that has a direct lineage to folk song

shortDefinitions: variety of something abstract

definitions: a particular tendency as part of a person's character

examples.text: there's a strain of Victorian rectitude in him

shortDefinitions: particular tendency as part of person's character
